reviewText:
Since the game's release I've put about eight hours into it, about split evenly between level progression and trying to get the various medals. It's proven to be a very addicting game, as I'm finding myself saying 'okay one more try' or 'let me see what this next level is' many times. It's also very fun, there's not much to it apart from the various platforming elements. There's still some stuff in the trailer I haven't gotten to yet, so the game doesn't throw everything at you right away, and each level is pretty different.

The platforming is nice and tight, as you're able to control how hard you jump, which comes in handy during speedruns when you just need to make a little hop. Respawns are quick, or if you want to restart the level, that's very fast as well. The camera element, or 'flashing', is interesting. Essentially, when you hit X, you make an afterimage of the background, which follows you for about two seconds before stopping, and then stays there for a few seconds more. You use this to create steps, lift enemies, and get to places you otherwise couldn't reach. It will take a bit of time to master this, as you'll have to learn when is the best time to jump before the platform halts its movement. But when you do you'll be able to move around levels like a pro.

Each level has a Time challenge and a Flash challenge. Bronze, Silver, and Gold medals for using the least amount of flashes possible, or beating it in the least amount of time. Sometimes getting gold for both happens at the same time, sometimes they're mutually exclusive. They're definitely challenging, but I wouldn't say they're unfair. Though it can be aggravating getting a time of 23.01 and you need to get a 23.00 to get the gold. But it's fun to see what shortcuts are in the levels. One that comes to mind can be completed in about five seconds, or over a minute, depending on if you know the trick or not. And when you're doing the speedruns, you'll often find the enemies are placed in juuust the right area to screw you over if you don't do it right. But then you get to do it and then you can laugh and laugh and laugh.

For the story, I haven't really delved into it yet. There are mementos you can find as collectibles. The main character is a photographer, and she's looking for somebody at the top of this tower. But anything other than that I either don't know or don't want to spoil. The memento give a history of the tower you're climbing, and what you're trying to accomplish, but it's not needed to enjoy the game. Only problem I have with this is there's no indication of what levels have mementos left uncollected, so you may want to write down what mementos you find in each level, as they're at least numbered.

The music is nice, I think there are about eleven tracks. They don't get repetitive and create a nice ambience for the game. Tempted to pick up the soundtrack myself.

I would estimate that if you were just going through the game, trying to get to the end, it would last you at least ten hours? I'm only at the halfway point myself, and it's definitely getting harder, so it'll take longer to beat the last levels. But it still hasn't reached unfair levels of difficulty, or Braid-level lateral reasoning to beat a puzzle. But then, that time doesn't count trying to get medals, or going back for mementos you missed. I did end up spending half an hour trying to get the two golds on one tricky level, but that feeling of satisfaction after I got them, oh, that was palpable.

There's also a level creator, but I haven't yet gone into that. But that's definitely something I'm looking forward to seeing after everyone develops some new levels. For the levels in the game, as I said before, there's a lot of variety. It changes the general theme of the level as you climb the tower, getting more mechanical as opposed to the stony architecture of the first levels, which is cool. There are moving platforms, switches you need to hit (or use monsters to hit), tiles that can't be flashed, tiles that need to be switched on to be flashed, and oh yes: no spikes whatsoever. If you die it's simply from falling down a pit or touching an enemy.

Definitely a good purchase, especially for the price. Absolutely recommended.

reviewText:
Camera Obscura is a small little indie title that I personally find equal parts charming and frustrating.  The puzzle mechanic here has a lot of potential, but the trailer is a bit misleading, as your after image moves with you for a second or so, then it stops, giving you lots of flexibility, but it can also be infuriating later on when you need finesse.

I like Camera Obscura.  The art style has a great deal of charm even if, in my opinion, the animation is a bit choppy here and there.  The story, hidden in the collectibles, is pretty moving and sad, equal parts a character study of our heroine and a look at the cult that built a tower to the sun.  The gameplay is surprisingly devious, to the point where it can get frustrating or be really innovative, depending.  I have spent some time yelling at my computer screen, but generally, it is pretty enjoyable.

Controls are fluid, but I HIGHLY recommend a usb controller, just for the difficult platforming sections.  The music is far and away the best part of the game, equal parts mysterious, calming, hectic, and adventerous.  This soundtrack is truly awesome.

The collectibles and the secret endings can be a bit frustrating as there are no guides to help with them, as of this posting, and the answers are seldom ever clear.  I got two of the three endings with a lot of experimentation.

I do recommend the game.  It's charming and fun, with a game mechanic that you will have to be really inventive with to use to the fullest.  As far as platformers go, it can be a bit frustrating, but as far as puzzlers go, it's deviously clever.

Camera Obscura.  Worth a playthrough, I think.

Camera Obscura is a platformer with an interesting mechanic, but some glaring issues when you're going for 100% completion. If you're not, it's an ok game, but you'll need some patience anyway. It has alot of unfair and unnecessarily annoying sections, that have not much to do with difficulty and platforming skills but are just plain bad level design.

- horrible collision detection with enemies. The hitbox is a box with always the same size, even though some animation frames make enemies very small, filling only a tiny spot in that box (slime's fall animation, for example, for those how already know the game)
- the menu has some unskippable slow fades and transitions. That gets annoying when you go through there alot. Selecting a level is especially tedious, you have to wait through multiple transitions when selecting a level.
- ugly graphics. There are alot of games out there that prove that 2D pixel graphics can look great. This game is the opposite.
- no restart level button, you have to go through the menu to restart the level, which you will do ALOT.
- no on screen timer. When you try to beat specific level times for medals and achievements, you have no idea how you are doing, until you see the end screen.
- when you start a level (coming from the previous level or the level select menu), there is a fade-in time during which you can't see anything, but the level timer has started anyway. For beating the times, you regularly will want to immediately restart the stage to start without the fade-in.
- the story is presented in text snippets. Yes, simple text, nothing else. Not even an interesting or eye-pleasing font.
- several levels have long boring sections where you are just walking or even just waiting for a moving platform, for example. And you will have to repeat those sections alot, because afterwards there is no checkpoint and some difficult section follows. You'll die alot, and you'll wait through the boring section again and again in each retry.

Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Camera Obscura with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.

I’m relatively predictable when it comes to my opinion of puzzle platformers; I don’t think they’re fun. Off the top of my head only two exceptions come to mind, the first being the Trine games, and the second being Thomas Was Alone. The key feature with both of those is that they’re more heavily story driven than their peers. Camera Obscura certainly did nothing to change my opinion of puzzle platforming, I didn’t have fun with the hour or so I spent with it, but I have to recommend it anyway.

The key mechanic is the ability to trigger a camera flash which creates an afterimage of the current visible terrain which you can then move around with your character. It’s difficult to explain on paper but the effect is really interesting. I have seen some games which allow for a certain segments of the screen to be captured and moved about but trying to work with all the visible terrain opens up many more possibilities as well as previously unconsidered challenges.
I didn’t find it fun but I think it’s a well made platformer with an intriguing mechanic worthy of some attention.

Overall considering the price this is a great game, easy to recommend since it's main mechanic (the photo taking) is well implemented and fun to use, it's just that sometimes it feels a bit overkill to use since, you see, the character can jump like, 1.8 meters up and all the platforms are like 1.81 meters up... this is a bit annoying and the graphic for the cave tile isn't the best in my opinion, seems like something taken out of a free tileset online (i've seen some) and for a tile SO used it's bad for it to get stale so soon.

Those are minor details that bother me but the game is really fun! can't go wrong with this cheap platformer :)

reviewText: The developers ploy of drawing comparisons with Braid and Fez may sound lofty, but to a degree they may be justified. The game mechanic that Camera Obscura revolves around is certainly original and clever. A flash from your camera creates a semi-permanent image of your surroundings that briefly stay with you and become the extra floors and walls that you need to aid your journey through each level. The retro styling is nice, though maybe a little spartan. My main complaint is a slight lack of crispness to the movement which kept me overshooting small platforms, but that might just be my poor-quality platforming skills and is certainly not anything close to game-breaking. In all I find that I have no problem recommending Camera Obscura to anyone who likes platform puzzlers, like Braid and Fez for example.

Can I shower this game in enough praise? No? Well, let me try anyway.

This game can both appeal to puzzle and platforming gamers alike. It brings an incredibly unique gimmick to the table- after-image platforms. One may think that these would make the game easier- however, they don't. Rather, they are a key mechanic in the puzzle aspect of the game.
One must think carefully, and move quickly, as these things can only be manipulated for a short time before they freeze. This gives the game a good flow, and the feeling of completing a puzzle is astoundingly positive.
From what short time I've spent with the game, the puzzles are fun and intuitive, the mechanic is unique and refreshing, the story is simple, yet spurs a sense of curiosity, and the new puzzle elements are introduced smoothly.

While this isn't the next Fez, this game certainly has potential to become one of the best indie platformers out there.
10/10, definitely a good buy.

reviewText:
Summary:
Surprising that the game can be gotten on the cheap with sales such as 24 cents, because the game's unique camera aspect actually works rather well. The idea being that you take a snapshot of the world, and you have a couple of seconds to walk and manipulate your snapshot in it. The mechanic is simple, but it works: it actually leads to some interesting puzzle solutions, and while the game isn't the greatest of lookers and definitely has flaws, it does feel rather different then many platformers out there. I picked it up at 24 cents, and I have to say, I definitely got my money's worth even an hour into it, and I seemingly still have a significant bit to go. Definitely worth the pocket change.

Gameplay and Video First Impressions:  https://youtu.be/cBWdCE5jDMY

Lists:
+:
Unique mechanic is different from other games and actually works out rather well: makes the game stand out a bit.
Environments play well into different “areas” and introduction of new mechanics are done rather well.
Creativity is rewarded here with using momentum, leading to interesting solutions. In particular, being able to get rid of enemies with it is rather neat.
There's collectables in interesting places to keep you looking for things.
Do like the animation of death, even if it's completely over the top at times. It's hilarious.-:
Visuals are definitely lacking. It's not the greatest of produced in terms of art direction.
Once in a while, the controls will feel a bit floaty.
First set of levels are definitely on the low difficulty section, but after the first section, it definitely opens up.
Some inconsistent rule sets. Now note, when it's inconsistent, I'll give them the fact that it's inconsistent where it “has” to be, aka the only way to do it.

reviewText:
In Camera Obscura you play a photographer scaling a decaying tower. Your camera has the strange ability to create after images of various platforms. These after images start off being able to slowly move based off your own movements but will eventually freeze up.
Once you learn to use the After Images this game becomes a lot easier and has a lot more variety in its puzzle solving.
Some of the puzzles are a little bit too frustrating. The game will sometimes task you with getting an enemy to a button to flip a door open, this enemy can easily be killed if you're not careful. These missions are some of the most frustrating missions ever.
The game is hard and sometimes unfair, however it is mostly enjoyable except for one thing, the level 8-2. This level is just awful, it's unclear what they want you to do and the flow is just horrible. The fact that every guide I found online was about ways to skip half of the level, should show you how hated it is. If you make it that far I suggest you learn how to skip it as well, it's not worth the effort doing it the way the designers wanted it done.
Thankfully the last level is fairly easy but has beautiful back grounds and a great musical score. It really does feel like the climax to your journey and is a great last level.

On the artistic side I found the back grounds to be pretty good. Some of them even are breath taking. While the sprite work is just average. The monsters don't seem to fit with the main characters art design, instead looking like your standard run of the mill monsters. It's a shame they couldn't come up with something more intresting than, slime, bat, bug. Though the ant eater is a bit different ( though they are Anteater games ).
However the true failure in this game, is the sprite animation. Slimes mysteriously grow butts, the main character jumps by just clapping her feet together. Your death animation is a silly double spin. The games animation is just a bit janky, nothing that upsets me, it just makes the game feel a bit cheap. ( Though the death animation IS hilarious ). However it does have artistic flourishes like having several idle animations that are pretty good, and even animating the scarf when she falls.

The story is given to you in bits and pieces, scattered across the levels in collectable polaroids. I collected them where I could and got above 75% of them, however I wish they didn't just use the polaroids. For example in Thomas was Alone, they had a voice over that gave you bits of the story and characterization. I would have liked something similar, maybe just text appearing as you played the level.
In the last level they have dialouge, but when you get to the end all you get is a samll image in the end credits.

All in all I think this game isn't the best game, but it has intresting mechanics and some fun levels with a story that is a bit charming. So for the price tag I say it's worth it to play, at least up till 8-2.

TLDR: It's 1.99 you get what you pay for. It's enjoyable for the most part but some levels will have you tearing out your hair.

reviewText:
So, one day someone says 'I want to make a videogame'. They put on their thinking cap, gather their resources, and tediously come up with a plan-of-attack. Everyone is sitting around the boardroom, spit-balling ideas, and someone says:

'Hey I got it - lets make one-trick-pony platformer with PS1 graphics! We will use the exact same mechanic as in Snapshot and essentially only use two buttons with looping ambient music. The art will be generic and so will all of the textures.'

Who's in?

---
Ok, lets be serious though - its not terrible, and the puzzle gimmick is not half-bad either, but it is not something I would tell a friend to spend five bucks on, period. It is more like a proof-of-concept with placeholder art and music, at this point.  If I had to guess, this was made with some easy access video game making software, and very few of the resources are custom for this game. I see people on the forums enjoy speedrunning this, and I guess I get that. I love video games, and I love to play lots of them, but everybody is limited by time - why play sub-standard titles? I don't mean this as an insult, but it has to be said.

I was gifted this game from a Steam account that regularly sends me titles to review. Thats fine, except most of what they send is garbage, which now has inflated review scores because they gift out so many copies. It irritates me a bit, to be honest.

Thanks for listening.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game.

I really did.

I saw the reviews and thought that it would be a solid game. Frankly, I'm unimpressed. The game consists of basic platforming aspects (that don't feel very good), along with one extra aspect, which is taking pictures of the surroundings and moves them with you.

I love the publishers who made this game- they made great games like Out There Somewhere, which is a fantastic game in my opinion. This game failed to really catch my attention.

The combat is annoying (Trying to crush the monsters which get caught on the afterimages and end up killing you anyways? Sounds like a fun time), which of course leads to entire levels being annoying when they require a ton of combat. Also, there are very little checkpoints in some levels, generally being the levels which really need them.

Now, looking at this game from a completionist point of view: if you plan to get this game for completionist, I beg you to reconsider. The achievements are ridiculous. You have to get a gold ranking on every sub-stage in the game. Every. Single. One. It's simply tedious. There's no rewarding aspect to it.

Frankly, I can't recommend this game. I didn't enjoy it. It wasn't fun. It was infuriating and I was just disappointed, especially after the developers created some really high-quality games that I loved. This game, in my opinion, is a no-go. Not really even worth it on sale. Yes, it has trading cards, but those really aren't worth it.

reviewText:
This is a Braid-esque platformer in that it relies around a novel mechanic and pretension to artistic statement. The story is hinted at and implied through collectible photo icons that contain snippets of text. Some are descriptions of a religious cult and some are mopey rememberences of a lost love. None are very captivating.

The gameplay is really good, though. The player can use a camera to clone certain parts of the scenery to create new platforms and solve jumping puzzles. That sounds strange, but it's a very intuitive and original mechanic. The difficulty scales gradually over the course of a robust 50 or 60 levels and many of the later ones especially are challenging and well-designed.

This is not a very polished game. The graphics are remarkably bad, although they are strikingly similar to some of the worst graphics from the 1990's -- a decade this game pays clear homage to. Is this some high-concept intentional design choice? If it is, it's too subtle for a philistine like me. All I can say is that many of the assests look like they were created at the wrong resolution and then stretched to the proper size at the last minute. Also there is a common bat" enemy that looks like it was drawn by a child. The music
recommended: is amusingly relaxing considering it is often the soundtrack to you dying over and over and over agin.\n\nQuibbles aside

reviewText:
This is a nice platformer with a unique mechanic. You use the after image your eyes see after a camera flash to make temporary platforms you can walk on to help you progress.  There is some story in this game but I have not played far enough through the came to comment on how good it is.
The game has a level editor and uses Steam Workshop to share user created content.  It has collectables for the OCD crowd.  For the $2.00 this game cost at the time of this review, I think it's a very good bang for your buck.

Graphics:  7/10

The 8 bit graphics are well done and fit the feel of the game well.

Sound:  7/10

The sounds and music fit the game and are of good quality.

Controls:  8/10

The controls feel crisp and precise. Platforming came easily on an Xbox 360 Hori gamepad.  The only reason I didn't give it a 10 is that when you are moving left or right, occasionally my character wouldn't move because I was pushing up a bit. I think the left/right window should be a little wider. Otherwise the controls in this game are spot on.

Gameplay:  8/10

The gameplay is fairly standard issue platforming fare but with the after image mechanic it finds it's own personality. The flash can make you have to think about how to get somewhere which I found gave this game a fun advantage over plain platforming.

Overall;  8/10

The value you get for you $2.00 is great. It's fun, it's different and well worth playing.
